ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: According to the passage, the doctors are trying to bridge the gap between potential patients and available donors by
ENGLISH.OPT1: restricting the number of organs a patient can receive.
ENGLISH.OPT2: using artificial organs in place of human organs.
ENGLISH.OPT3: researching alternative ways of treatments which can replace organ transplantation.
ENGLISH.OPT4: considering using the organs of donors whose age exceeds the age limits on organ donations.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 1 to 6: The passage given below is followed by a set of six questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

As organ transplantation becomes increasingly successful, surgeons are facing a new series of thorny practical and ethical issues.

The fundamental problem is that there are far more potential patients than donors. At least 17,000 Americans are now waiting for an organ.

As a practical matter, doctors are trying innovation and improvisation to expand the pool of donors. For instance, they are moving to relax age restrictions on donations. They have even used organs from 70-year-old adults in children.

On the ethical issues, however, doctors are finding that improvised solutions are either inappropriate or impossible. With the number of multiple-organ transplants growing, for example, society must decide whether limits should be set on the number of organs one person receives.

In reconsidering the age restriction on donations, doctors are charting new biological territory. Physicians have been reluctant to transplant older organs that might be damaged or might not function long. But the existing standards reflect arbitrary limits. For kidneys it is about 60 years, while for livers it is 55. For hearts, it is 45 for women and 40 for men. The age differences generally reflect the relative incidence of organ damage from clogged arteries.

""The chronological cutoff doesn"t make a lot of sense because someone who dies at 75 can be biologically younger than someone at 50,"" said Dr. Calvin R. Stiller, the head of transplant surgery at the University of Western Ontario in London and a leader in transplantation.

In June, Dr. William J. Wall from the Western Ontario team took the liver from a 70-year-old man and gave it to a 10-year-old boy. The liver has functioned well for six months. …

The crucial factor in using an older organ is the condition of the blood vessels. ""If they are open or easily reparable, we use the organ,"" Dr. Stiller said.

In one unusual case, a Western Ontario transplant team headed by Dr. Neil McKenzie removed a heart from a 58-year-old man who died of a stroke. Finding the arteries blocked by fatty deposits, the surgeons performed a bypass operation on the heart and then transplanted it into a patient dying of heart disease.

The Western Ontario team has performed 16 other heart transplants with organs donated by individuals aged 46 to 58.

Doctors at Western Ontario are also testing the use of human hearts as bridges to keep patients alive while they seek a better match or stronger heart. This runs parallel to the efforts in many medical centers to use artificial hearts as bridges.

Dr. Stiller"s team has used human hearts as bridges in five cases. The hypothesis is that a human organ involves less risk and cost, even if it does not achieve peak performance. The surgeons also knew that if the heart failed, they could remove it and implant an artificial heart.

In three of the five cases, the temporary human heart transplant did the job until a better heart was found after about a week. In the other two cases, the ""temporary"" heart has become a permanent, well-functioning transplant. Both patients are still alive; one has survived for 17 months with the heart. Doctors are also turning to living donors for organs that they had not expected to be able to use. In the past, doctors were limited to removing one of two kidneys from a living donor, or taking a portion of the pancreas, which lies deep in the abdomen.

But in recent months, doctors in four countries have taken a portion, or lobe, of the liver from a parent and have given it to a child with fatal liver disease. Two such transplants were done at the University of Chicago in recent weeks.

Members of the transplant team are optimistic that by using a living family member for the donation, they will not have to wait as long to find a good match with a cadaver liver. As a result, the tiny patients may be healthier when they receive the transplants.

In the first procedure in Chicago, both the recipient and the donor suffered complications. The infant has had three additional operations to stop bleeding after the transplant. And the infant"s mother had to have her spleen removed because doctors accidentally nicked it during the operation on her liver.

The potential for such complications have made many people uneasy about using the liver or pancreas because there are no backups. In contrast, if a kidney fails, a patient can turn to dialysis.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: Why does the author mention that the “existing standards reflect arbitrary limits” (para 5)?
ENGLISH.OPT1: The existing chronological age limits for organs are set randomly and are not backed by proper research.
ENGLISH.OPT2: The biological age of an organ is more important than the chronological age in deciding the organ’s suitability for transplantation.
ENGLISH.OPT3: The existing biological age limits for organs is not different for men and women.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Organ transplantations in which the age of donors exceeds the prescribed age limits have become commonplace.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: Which of the following has not been mentioned as an application of the ancient practice of dowsing in the passage?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Dowsers have successfully located springs of water.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Dowsers have shown miners where to dig for metal.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Dowsers have been able to find explosive devices hidden underground.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Dowsers have been able to track down murderers over long distances.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 7 to 9: The passage given below is followed by a set of three questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

Psychic archaeology is the process of using psychic abilities to locate objects of centuries past. This recently charted path may open possibilities of the discoveries of new and interesting histories in the human race. Whereas conventional archaeology practices can draw the objects, buildings, and even people forth, psychic archaeology can bring life and a sense of being to these discoveries and how they matter in ancient people’s lives. From these re-routed stories we can learn more about our species’ past, and in turn learn more about ourselves. …

There are several different methods psychic archaeologists use to uncover the mysteries of the past. Dowsing, the ancient practice of discovering ‘earthed’ things such as water and metal, has been recorded as being practiced as early as the 15th century. It is utilized by intuitive diggers to find electromagnetic photo-fields, which are said to radiate from man-made objects of six months or older. This is done using either metal rods, or various types of branches. The dowsing rod or branch moves in accordance with the desired object, leading the treasure hunter to the desired object. This practice was used even in the military in attempts to find underground explosive devices.

Psychic George McMullen, however, used the ability of psychometry, which is the knack of sensing the history of an object by holding it. By holding an object he could sense the owner, when, where, and how it was made, and whether or not the owner had passed away. Not only could he identify the history of an object, but he could also sense the culture aspects surrounding the object and its owners. Simply by standing over an unexcavated site, he knew the time period, race, and sociological aspects of the oldest remains that lay beneath him. One can see how skills like this could be extremely helpful on a site, as knowing what you are digging for and how to get to it is a rarity in the craft. Other psychics used different tools, such as remote viewing, precognitive dreaming, and channeling. …

Within the past century, many have been fighting to have psychic archaeology appreciated as a resourceful practice in the field. The merge of science and intuition may seem unlikely to some, but it has proved to be effective in aiding the uncovering of ancient societies and their secrets. Many skeptics have been turned into believers after the psychic information given aligned with the cold, hard, scientific facts, and even took them a step further, mapping out knowledge that would not have been known earlier. Hopefully we can use this new source of information as a stepping stone to new and interesting discoveries.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: What is the tone of the author in the passage?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Dubious
ENGLISH.OPT2: Hopeful
ENGLISH.OPT3: Phlegmatic
ENGLISH.OPT4: Reminiscing

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: Which of the following is definitely false about psychometry as can be inferred from the passage?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Psychometry is the supposed ability to discover facts about an event or person by touching inanimate objects associated with them.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Psychometry can give one a glimpse into the historical background, cultural overview and other sociological aspects of the objects of centuries past.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Psychometry includes methods such as remote viewing, precognitive dreaming, and channeling.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Psychometry can help in discovering new and interesting histories in the human race.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 7 to 9: The passage given below is followed by a set of three questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

Psychic archaeology is the process of using psychic abilities to locate objects of centuries past. This recently charted path may open possibilities of the discoveries of new and interesting histories in the human race. Whereas conventional archaeology practices can draw the objects, buildings, and even people forth, psychic archaeology can bring life and a sense of being to these discoveries and how they matter in ancient people’s lives. From these re-routed stories we can learn more about our species’ past, and in turn learn more about ourselves. …

There are several different methods psychic archaeologists use to uncover the mysteries of the past. Dowsing, the ancient practice of discovering ‘earthed’ things such as water and metal, has been recorded as being practiced as early as the 15th century. It is utilized by intuitive diggers to find electromagnetic photo-fields, which are said to radiate from man-made objects of six months or older. This is done using either metal rods, or various types of branches. The dowsing rod or branch moves in accordance with the desired object, leading the treasure hunter to the desired object. This practice was used even in the military in attempts to find underground explosive devices.

Psychic George McMullen, however, used the ability of psychometry, which is the knack of sensing the history of an object by holding it. By holding an object he could sense the owner, when, where, and how it was made, and whether or not the owner had passed away. Not only could he identify the history of an object, but he could also sense the culture aspects surrounding the object and its owners. Simply by standing over an unexcavated site, he knew the time period, race, and sociological aspects of the oldest remains that lay beneath him. One can see how skills like this could be extremely helpful on a site, as knowing what you are digging for and how to get to it is a rarity in the craft. Other psychics used different tools, such as remote viewing, precognitive dreaming, and channeling. …

Within the past century, many have been fighting to have psychic archaeology appreciated as a resourceful practice in the field. The merge of science and intuition may seem unlikely to some, but it has proved to be effective in aiding the uncovering of ancient societies and their secrets. Many skeptics have been turned into believers after the psychic information given aligned with the cold, hard, scientific facts, and even took them a step further, mapping out knowledge that would not have been known earlier. Hopefully we can use this new source of information as a stepping stone to new and interesting discoveries.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: According to the passage, what does Ms. Jeon refer to as a “bad situation” in para 2?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Tap water is not safe to drink.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Though tap water is safe to drink, consumers are purchasing bottled water.
ENGLISH.OPT3: The bright blue bottles that Ms. Jeon is using are made of paper and not plastic but still cause harm to the environment.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Consumers are reducing their intake of sugary beverages and prefer drinking water instead.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 10 to 15: The passage given below is followed by a set of six questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

On a recent morning over avocado toast and world-renowned New York City tap water, Grace Jeon expounded on the virtues of public drinking water. Considering that the company she runs makes its money selling bottled water, her enthusiasm might have seemed a little strange. Ms. Jeon held up one of her company’s bright blue opaque bottles, which are made mostly of paper, not plastic. “I would never advocate drinking this over tap,” Ms. Jeon said. But the reality is that more consumers are moving to bottled water as they cut down on drinking sugary beverages. Her company has positioned its bottled water, called Just Water, as the next best thing to tap. …

Most tap water in the United States is safe to drink, according to environmental groups. But many consumers prefer the convenience of bottled water, and are willing to pay for it. As Ms. Jeon sees it, she is making the best of a bad situation. Her product is less harmful to the environment and creates fewer carbon emissions than energy-intensive plastic. In the process, she is also helping the struggling city of Glens Falls, N.Y. …

When Just Water first asked the mayor, Jack Diamond, about sourcing and bottling water in his city, he initially thought the offer was too good to be true. When he has been approached by companies in the past, in general, “it’s not so much what they’re going to do for us, but what can we do for them,” he said. “The roles were reversed with this company.”

Just Water might be a boon to Glens Falls, but if environmental groups like Ban the Bottle had their way, people would take reusable water bottles with them everywhere, and bottled water would be unnecessary in most situations. That fight, however, has remained a losing battle. In 2014, annual bottled water consumption in the United States reached a peak of 34 gallons a person. …

The reason for bottled water “has nothing to do with the availability of good, clean appealing water in the country. It has to do with how we live,” Mr. Fishman said. “It has to do with the disappearance of good water fountains – with the failure of water fountain companies to innovate cool, interesting, appealing water fountains.”

Ms. Jeon said she thought she had left the bottled water industry for good when Drew Fitzgerald, the founder of Just Water, approached her with his idea to make everyday packaged items more environmentally friendly, starting with bottled water. He was an adviser to Prime, an organization that helps foundations and wealthy families finance technologies that reduce greenhouse gas emissions. And as it turns out, Mr. Fitzgerald’s hometown is Glens Falls. …

“There are bigger issues to bottled water than just what the package is made out of,” said Mae Wu, a staff lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council. These include the environmental costs of shipping water, the effects of removing water from communities and water bottle waste.

Of course, water bottles can be recycled. “All bottled water containers are 100 percent recyclable and many bottled water companies are already using recycled plastic in their bottles,” said Chris Hogan, a spokesman for the International Bottled Water Association. “As an industry, we are always looking for ways to strengthen existing programs and help to expand recycling efforts ever further,” he wrote.

Just Water isn’t the only company offering an alternative to traditional bottled water. Boxed Water packages its water in a gable-top paper box, much like a milk carton. Fred Water delivers water in hard plastic flasks and encourages drinkers to reuse the bottles. Green Sheep offers consumers water in aluminum bottles, which is more readily recycled than plastic. Like Just Water, many of these companies are committed to improving the environment. Traditional beverage companies, such as Nestlé Waters North America, which includes brands such as Arrowhead, Deer Park and Poland Springs, made up 23 percent of water bottle sales last year.

There are no signs that shoppers will be sipping less bottled water anytime soon. “As people have more money in their pocket it stands that they’d be more willing to pay a little extra for water or something else that claimed to have environmental or other benefits.”…

Ms. Jeon claimed she would rather see the tide go in the opposite direction. “It’s not about getting more people to drink bottled water but if you’re going to drink bottled water, consider a better option than the current choice.”

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: What could be the reason for increased bottled water usage, according to Mr. Fishman?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Pure and visually appealing drinking water is available in plenty.
ENGLISH.OPT2: People prefer branded water bottles and bottled water is safer than tap water.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Paucity of appealing drinking water fountains.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Many more companies are now designing cool and appealing water bottles.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: Which of the following is an example of endowment bias?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Unwillingness of a person who arranges for sale of a property at less than what it was purchased for.
ENGLISH.OPT2: The owner of a car tends to ascribe a higher value to his car as compared to a similar car not his own.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Customers tend to bargain for any product that they are about to purchase.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Unskilled individuals usually overestimate their abilities whereas skilled individuals underestimate their abilities.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 16 to 18: The passage given below is followed by a set of three questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

Often, you’ll hear people say that you should “trust your instincts” when making decisions. But are first instincts always the best?

Psychological research has shown many times that no, they are often no better – and in many cases worse – than a revision or change. Despite enormous popular belief that first instincts are special, dozens of experiments have found that they are not.

While that may be a useful fact to bring up in an academic discussion, anyone who has ever made a decision in real life will undoubtedly reply: But I remember times when I made a correct choice, then changed my mind and was wrong.

This happens for two reasons: First, humans naturally have something called an endowment bias, where we feel strongly attached to things we already have (our first instinct, in this case).

We don’t want to give it up, and we feel especially bad when we give it up and it turns out later to be correct. We remember these instances vividly and thus they seem to be very common, even though all research shows that they are less common.

The second reason is more obvious: sometimes first instincts actually are correct. The problem is figuring out when to trust yourself and when to change course.

The solution may lie within the realm of “metacognition,” the ability to “think about thinking” and use those thoughts to monitor and control behaviour. …

I was amazed that my undergraduate students sometimes seemed to lack the ability. They were always surprised at their exam grades; some would significantly overestimate their performance, while others underestimated it. They would also believe their first instincts were special, even when their own behaviors – successfully revising answers – showed otherwise.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: According to the passage, which of the following is a difference between the methods of anthropologists and geneticists?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Geneticists gave importance to clock rate while anthropologists did not know the clock rate.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Geneticists relied on the rate of genetic mutations while anthropologists relied on the phylogenetic rate.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Anthropologists have used genetic dating methods to show that genetic differences accumulate over time while geneticists considered the age of fossils as a means of calculating evolutionary splits.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Anthropologists have used more advanced methods of genetic dating than geneticists.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 19 to 24: The passage given below is followed by a set of six questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

In order to date evolutionary divergences – when ancestors split from Neanderthals, chimpanzees and other relatives – geneticists have relied on the molecular clock i.e. the idea that genetic mutations accumulate at a steady rate over time. Specifically this concerns mutations that become neutral substitutions, or lasting changes to letters of the genetic code that do not affect an organism’s chances of surviving and reproducing.

If such mutations arise clocklike, then calculating the time since two organisms shared common ancestors should be as easy as dividing the number of genetic differences between them by the mutation rate. But you need to know the rate.

For decades, anthropologists used fossil calibration to generate the so-called phylogenetic rate (a phylogeny is a tree showing evolutionary relationships). They took the geologic age of fossils from evolutionary branch points and calculated how fast mutations must have arisen along the resulting lineages.

For example, the earliest fossils on the human branch after our split with chimps are identified by the fact that they seem to have walked on two legs; bipedalism is the first obvious difference that distinguishes our evolutionary lineage of hominins from that of chimps. These fossils are 7-6 million years old, and therefore the chimp-human split should be around that age. Dividing the number of genetic differences between living chimps and humans by 6.5 million years provides a mutation rate. …

But genetic dating got messy in 2010, when improvements to DNA sequencing allowed researchers to determine the number of genetic differences between parents and their children. Known as pedigree analysis, this provides a more direct measurement of the current mutation rate within one generation, rather than an average over millions of years. Pedigree analysis counts 60-some mutations every generation; that converts to a rate approximately half the phylogenetic estimate – meaning evolutionary events would be twice as old. …

It turns out that among primates, the molecular clock varies significantly by species, sex, and mutation type. A recent study found that New World monkeys (i.e. monkeys of the Americas like marmosets and squirrel monkeys) have substitution rates about 64% higher than apes (including humans). Within apes, rates are about 7% higher in gorillas and 2% higher in chimpanzees, compared to humans. … It’s now clear that one mutation rate cannot determine the dates for all divergences relevant to human evolution. However, researchers can secure the timeline for important evolutionary events by combining new methods of genetic dating with fossils and geologic ages.

Innovative computational methods have incorporated reproductive variables into calculations. By taking into account ages of reproduction in both sexes, age of male puberty, and sperm production rates, researchers have estimated split times that accord with the fossil record.

Another new approach has analysed mutations that are mainly independent of DNA replication. It seems that certain classes of mutations, related to DNA damage, do behave more clocklike.

And some researchers have focused on ancient DNA. Comparing human fossils from the past 50,000 years to humans today, suggests a mutation rate that agrees with pedigree analysis.

At least one evolutionary split was pinned down in 2016, after ancient DNA was extracted from 430,000 year-old hominin fossils from Sima de los Huesos, Spain. The Sima hominins looked like early members of the Neanderthal lineage based on morphological similarities. This hypothesis fit the timing of the split between Neanderthals and modern humans based on pedigree analysis (765,000-550,000 years ago), but did not work with the phylogenetic estimate (383,000-275,000 years ago).

Where do the Sima hominins belong on our family tree? Were they ancestors of both Neanderthals and modern humans, just Neanderthals, or neither?

DNA answered this definitively. The Sima hominins belong to the Neanderthal branch after it split with modern humans. Moreover, the result provides a firm time point in our family tree, suggesting that the pedigree rate works for this period of human evolution.

Neanderthals and modern humans likely diverged between 765,000-550,000 years ago. Other evolutionary splits may soon be clarified as well, thanks to advances brought about by the mutation rate debates. Someday soon, when you see a chimp, you may be able to salute your great, great… great grandparent, with the correct number of “greats.”

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: What can be inferred from the statement “But genetic data got messy in 2010” (para 5)?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Till that time geneticists did not take into account pedigree analysis.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Methods used in 2010 led to the conclusion being arrived at being proved incorrect.
ENGLISH.OPT3: The results of pedigree analysis did not conform to the phylogenetic estimates.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Genetic dating methods employed in 2010 could not fix the timeline for human evolution.

Within apes, rates are about 7% higher in gorillas and 2% higher in chimpanzees, compared to humans. … It’s now clear that one mutation rate cannot determine the dates for all divergences relevant to human evolution. However, researchers can secure the timeline for important evolutionary events by combining new methods of genetic dating with fossils and geologic ages.

Innovative computational methods have incorporated reproductive variables into calculations. By taking into account ages of reproduction in both sexes, age of male puberty, and sperm production rates, researchers have estimated split times that accord with the fossil record.

Another new approach has analysed mutations that are mainly independent of DNA replication. It seems that certain classes of mutations, related to DNA damage, do behave more clocklike.

And some researchers have focused on ancient DNA. Comparing human fossils from the past 50,000 years to humans today, suggests a mutation rate that agrees with pedigree analysis.

At least one evolutionary split was pinned down in 2016, after ancient DNA was extracted from 430,000 year-old hominin fossils from Sima de los Huesos, Spain. The Sima hominins looked like early members of the Neanderthal lineage based on morphological similarities. This hypothesis fit the timing of the split between Neanderthals and modern humans based on pedigree analysis (765,000-550,000 years ago), but did not work with the phylogenetic estimate (383,000-275,000 years ago).

Where do the Sima hominins belong on our family tree? Were they ancestors of both Neanderthals and modern humans, just Neanderthals, or neither?

DNA answered this definitively. The Sima hominins belong to the Neanderthal branch after it split with modern humans. Moreover, the result provides a firm time point in our family tree, suggesting that the pedigree rate works for this period of human evolution.

Neanderthals and modern humans likely diverged between 765,000-550,000 years ago. Other evolutionary splits may soon be clarified as well, thanks to advances brought about by the mutation rate debates. Someday soon, when you see a chimp, you may be able to salute your great, great… great grandparent, with the correct number of “greats.”

DIRECTIONS for questions 33 and 34: The following question has a paragraph from which the last sentence has been left incomplete. From the given options, choose the one that completes the paragraph in the most appropriate way.

Six million American men will be diagnosed with depression this year. But millions more suffer silently, unaware that their problem has a name or unwilling to seek treatment. In a confessional culture in which Americans are increasingly obsessed with their health, it may seem clichéd – men are from Mars, women from Venus, and all that – to say that men tend not to take care of themselves and are reluctant to own up to mental illness. But the facts suggest that, well, men tend not to take care of themselves and are reluctant to own up to mental illness. Although depression is emotionally crippling and has numerous medical implications – some of them deadly – many men fail to recognize the symptoms. Instead of talking about their feelings, men may mask them with alcohol, drug abuse, gambling, anger or by becoming workaholics. _____________________

ENGLISH.OPT3: As awareness of the problem grows – among the public and medical professionals alike – the stigma surrounding male depression is beginning to lift.

Harry Potter's phenomenal popularity has put his creator, J. K. Rowling, amongst the giants of English literature, with the Bronte sisters and William Shakespeare. The first of the seven books by Rowling, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, is now part of the English literature A-level curriculum in Britain. This move by the governing authorities has sparked fears that it will dumb down academic standards. Inevitably, several teachers have argued that Harry Potter is not appropriate material for teaching ... that it is fun, but not deserving of being studied with Great Expectations or Far from the Madding Crowd. What, may one ask, is wrong with studying something fun? Are students of English literature doomed to studying only pre-20th century works? Must English literature be associated with works of gravitas that tend to inspire less-than-enthusiastic responses from students? _____________________________________________
ENGLISH.OPT1: Using a piece of work that means something to students to introduce them to literary criticism isn't dumbing down, it's smart.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Popular culture has acquired more than just a patina of respectability in recent times and is a window into the mood of society.
ENGLISH.OPT3: The knee-jerk opposition to the move can only be described as short-sighted at best and prejudiced at worst.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Isn't there something to be said for making the syllabus more relevant and accessible to students?
